title: What is the significance of wave number (quantum mechanics, waves, acoustics, physics)? - Quora

response.answer_text: The wave number [math]k[/math] conveys wavelength [math]\lambda[/math] and is a convenient parameter to use when calculating the wave with a cosine or sine function. [math]k = \frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}[/math] [math]\cos \left( k z \right)[/math] See how easy the cosine function is to write? Here is another way to look at wave number. The full equation for a wave would be something like [math]\Psi \left(t,z \right) = A \cos \left( k z - \omega t \right)[/math] The parameter [math]\omega[/math] is the angular frequency and it describes how quickly the wave oscillates with time so it multiples time [math]t[/math]. Similarly, the wave number [math]k[/math] describes how quickly the wave oscillates with distance so it multiplies [math]z[/math]. If you want to learn more about waves, checkout the series of excellent and highly graphical videos under Topic 6 here: Electromagnetic Field Theory - EMPossible

Any choice of units-of-measure is done for the convenience of the user. Light has been traditionally measured by wavelengths because we couldn’t measure frequency back then. Frequency is a more convenient parameter because it is constant for a wave, while wavelength changes as the wave goes from medium to medium. Wavenumber is a frequency-like measure, for situations where you want some parameter, like energy, to increase when your independent variable (wavenumber) increases.
